qas.question: Which company introduced hybrid incandescent bulbs?
How much more efficient are Halogena Energy Saver bulbs compared to incandescents?
What company first marketed light bulbs using the reflective capsule technique to increase energy efficiency?
What is the theoretical maximum efficiency of reflective capsule bulbs?
What is the maximum efficiency of reflective capsule bulbs as tested in labs?
Which company did not introduce hybrid incandescent bulbs?

plausible_answers.text: by legislation in various countries mandating increased bulb efficiency

qas.question: What did not prompt Philips to introduce the hybrid incandescent bulbs?
What is 40% less efficient than traditional incandescent?
Which concept was not pioneered by Duro-Test in 1980?

context: Prompted <b6_0>by legislation in various countries mandating increased bulb efficiency<b6_0/>, new "hybrid" incandescent bulbs have been introduced by <a0_0><b5_0>Philips<b5_0/><a0_0/>. The <b7_0><b8_0>"Halogena Energy Saver" incandescents<b8_0/><b7_0/> can produce about 23 lm/W; about <a1_0>30 percent<a1_0/> more efficient than traditional incandescents, by using a <b9_0>reflective capsule<b9_0/> to reflect formerly wasted infrared radiation back to the filament from which it can be re-emitted as visible light. This concept was pioneered by <a2_0>Duro-Test<a2_0/> in 1980 with a commercial product that produced 29.8 lm/W. More advanced reflectors based on interference filters or photonic crystals can theoretically result in higher efficiency, up to a limit of about <a3_0>270 lm/W<a3_0/> (40% of the maximum efficacy possible). Laboratory proof-of-concept experiments have produced as much as <a4_0>45 lm/W<a4_0/>, approaching the efficacy of compact fluorescent bulbs.
